Dear Mr. McKeage:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 8/14/23. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6692.
Sincerely,
Stephanie S Meeuwenberg, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4506 Fire drills and telephone.
(1) There shall be quarterly emergency fire drills for each
staff shift. Two of the drills shall include evacuations,
unless approved by the department, in writing, as
clinically contraindicated. Where a facility has a 24-hour
staff shift, the emergency drills shall be conducted at
different times of the day and night. Written records shall
be maintained for each drill indicating the date and time
of the drill and, where evacuation was a part of the drill,
the approximate evacuation time.

The Qualified Fire Inspection provide a C rating as the fire Drills for July were not
completed by either shift. The facility will run extra drills in August to make up for the
2 missed drills.
R 400.4524 Fire detection; large facilities.
(8) Fire alarm systems shall be tested and maintained on an
annual basis in accordance with NFPA 72. Smoke detector
calibration shall be done as recommended. The licensee shall
keep a record of fire alarm maintenance.
The Qualified Fire Inspection provide a C rating as the last fire alarm system
inspection report has deficiencies present. Duct detectors need to be
tested/inspected and smoke detector sensitivity testing is overdue. The facility has
contacted the fire alarm Contractor to schedule the fire alarm testing to clear current
deficiencies.
R 400.4532 Fire extinguishers.
(1) All required fire extinguishers shall be subjected to a
maintenance check at least once a year. Each fire extinguisher
shall have a tag or label attached indicating the month and year
maintenance was performed and identifying the person or
company performing the service, as specified by NFPA
Standard 10.
The Qualified Fire Inspection provide a C rating as the fire extinguishers facility wide
are overdue for annual maintenance. The fire extinguishers expired July 2023. The
fire extinguisher Contractor has been contacted to schedule the annual
maintenance.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 7 acceptable corrective action plans during this licensing
period. The corrective action plans have been monitored throughout the period

under review and they have completed the actions steps required of them. They
have made significant improvments in staffing, training, decreasing seclusions, and
improving the treatment and programming for the youth. Throughout the period
under review the staff have been interviewed at random and are all aware of the
new expectations for restraints, supervision, seclusion, and documentation. The
facility is in compliance with all corrective action plans.
Financial Overview
N/A, Governmental Organization
PREA compliance
Bay Pines Center completed their most recent PREA audit on November 5, 2021.
They were found in compliance with all applicable PREA standards, and no
corrective actions were required. Bay Pines Center will participate in another PREA
audit in the fall of 2023.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator said during this period under review Bay Pines Center has
made some significant changes and improvements to the overall treatment and
programming for the youth. The Chief Administrator said there were several staffing
improvements throughout the facility for staff to be moved into different positions,
new positions were created, additional staffing was approved, and the criteria for
working directly with the youth was changed to allow for more diverse applicants.
These staffing changes has boosted morale within the facility and has allowed the
facility to hire to their capacity and are now fully staffed. This staffing increase has
allowed the programming and supervision of the youth to also change. The facility is
operating at a 1:4 ratio during the day which has allowed for more relationship
building and time for staff to work with the youth are more of their individual goals as
well. The Chief Administrator said with the staffing changes and programming
changes the seclusions for youth has drastically decreased. The Chief Administrator
said the treatment for youth has improved with the ability to promote group leaders,
hire a clinical leader, and increase the amount of licensed social workers that are on
staff. The facility has also improved many areas of independent living skill
opportunity for the youth, including obtaining green house and planting a garden that
the youth have been able to assist with and learn about; obtaining chickens and
getting them certified by 4-H in order to use their eggs which the youth have been
able to participate in building their structures, learning about the animal, participate
in 4-H and are planning to participate in the showing the chickens at the county fair;
obtaining a new appliances for the kitchen and offering cooking classes through
safe-serve for the youth. Overall, there have been no unplanned discharges. The
Chief Administrator reported the corrective actions have been implemented
throughout this period under review and many are apart of the daily routines at Bay
Pines Center.
Staff and Youth Interviews

The staff all reported feeling well supported and trained throughout the period under
review. The staff all reported a change in programming for the better and reported
seeing more progress with the youth they serve. The staff were all knowledgeable
about the restraint rules as well as the current seclusion variance.
The youth all reported feeling safe and having all of their needs met at the facility.
None of the youth reported concerns with staff or programming. None of the youth
reported incidents of improper seclusions.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The facility is clean and in good condition. The facility has new paint in most areas,
new flooring in several pods, additional updates to the gymnasium, a library
established in a former office, new appliances in the kitchen, a green house and
garden the youth are able to utilize, and remodeling of one pod to expand the
common area. The medication is double locked on each pod. The kitchen is well
maintained and has the menu posted along with a whiteboard to update any
changes to the menu that day. There were no concerns noted during the walk
through.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the facility will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
